conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Hey John! I haven't seen you in ages! What's new? What have you been up to?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Pete! Nice to see you Well, on top the norm, you know, wife and kids and work, I've actually gotten into doing some trading.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Trading? You, big guy? What are you trading?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Currencies.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Currencies? As in Euros, Dollars, Pounds and Rupees?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: It's called Forex. Foreign Exchange. The great thing about it is that I don't have to invest a huge amount. I put in a margin deposit and then I can buy and sell up to 100 times that much!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I don't understand. You're buying and selling money?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You got it! Just last night I made USD 150!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Last night?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah! It's a 24 hour market! I had bought some RMB earlier at a low asking price but last night it appreciated drastically so I made a split second decision and sold all my RMB at an amazing bid! I've also done some trading with CHF and AUD and HKD. I've made some good profits but I've also suffered some losses. It depends on a lot of factors just like any other market. In total I've made about USD 500 in the past few months.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: You're kidding! I'm on! Where do I sign up?

title: EnglishPod 243 - Talking to a Travel Agent

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Welcome to Perfect Getaway Tours . How can I help you?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I would like to plan a surprise getaway for me and my wife.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Very well, we have a couple of different options such as beaches, the wilderness, the countryside or even going to a spa for the weekend.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I think something in the countryside would be nice.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Perfect! This package includes round-trip flights to New Hampshire . A free airport pick- up is included. Our VIP limousine will pick you up and provide you with complimentary champagne and finger foods to soften the thirty-minute ride to the countryside.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Sounds good! What is the hotel that we will be staying at like?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: That is the best part. Your hotel is actually an old country villa that has been restored and refurbished to accommodate a maximum of that is guests. You will enjoy an intimate and private time in this very spacious and warm N Included in the price is three meals a day, excluding beverages. You can choose to eat at the fabulous restaurant that offers a stunning view of the lush, green gardens. If you prefer, your own private butler can arrange your meal to be served in your room or outside on our terrace.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Wow! This sounds like something my wife would really enjoy! Are there any outdoor activities we can take part in ?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Of course! The hotel has a stable with beautiful stallions for a very romantic horseback ride along the country trail. You can also go fishing to the nearby lake or visit the local vineyard.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I'm sold ! I want to book this trip. I don't care what it costs! Money is no object !

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Welcome to our show! Today, I am going to show you how to make the perfect mouthwatering sandwich! Are you ready? Let's get started !

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Let's start with the basics :bread. Bread is an important ingredient here. You need to remember one thing -choose the bread according to the following criteria :freshness, crumb and color. If you want a closed sandwich I recommend you first toast your bread in a toaster or oven, or grill it slightly until it gets a light brown color.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Now that our bread is ready, let's talk about the ingredients ! Of course, each person's palate is different, but I'm going to give you a few tips that you'll be able to use when turning any sandwich into the perfect sandwich. I would strongly recommend you put fresh vegetables in your sandwich.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Do not undervalue them as they play a big role in forming the taste and will make the sandwich more refreshing and light. The best choices here are evident- cucumbers, tomatoes, onions, sweet pepper pepper or chilli, lettuce and, of course, herbs- you can't go wrong with them. As for aubergines, mushrooms and asparagus, I would recommend you first grill them slightly with a little touch of olive oil.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Last but not least, we have a wide variety of condiments that we can add to our perfect sandwich. We can be subtle and just add a touch of salt and pepper, or we can combine mustard sauce, mayonnaise, ketchup or even caviar to achieve a stronger flavor! It's always a good idea to cut your sandwich in triangles or manageable pieces to avoid all your ingredients falling out and staining your shirt!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: That's all the time we have for today, but join us next time where we'll be going over how to make the perfect lasagna! Till next time!

conversation.text: Alright, settle down everyone. As part of this school's curriculum we'll be covering sex ed this week.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Now I want everyone to take this class seriously, sexual education is very important and I want you to ask as many questions as you can think of. Remember, there are no stupid questions here.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Miss Carlton? What exactly is sexual education? Are you going to teach us like Kama sutra stuff like that?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: No Jason, that's not exactly what sex ed is. Basically, we will talk about sexually transmitted diseases, contraceptives and how the male and female bodies work.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: My older sister is in college and she takes what she and her friends call the pill. I never really understood what that is, but I know it has to do with sex or something.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Good point Jason! This will be the topic of our first class, contraceptives. As you mentioned, the pill is one of the many that exist. The birth control pill is taken daily by a woman in order to prevent unwanted pregnancy, but it does not protect her from contracting STD's from an infected person. Another popular method is using condoms. This is probably the best method if you have sex, since it not only prevents a woman from getting pregnant but also protects both from STD's. Yes Jason?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What are condoms made out of? How exactly is it that a woman gets pregnant?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Condoms are usually made out of an elastic material called Latex. As for your other question, that's a whole new class.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Continuing with our class, today we are going to study briefly the miracle of life. Many of you may think you already know how babies come to be, but I am sure that some of the things that we will be talking about today may surprise you. Billy can you turn on the projector please? Thanks. Ok, does anyone know what this is?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Looks like a goat head to me!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Nice try, but this is a woman’s womb which contains her uterus and ovaries. The ovaries. are packed with eggs and each month during the middle of the menstrual cycle, the ripest one will be sucked up by one of the fallopian tubes. This is called ovulation and the exact time of ovulation depends on the length of your cycle. In an average 28 day cycle, ovulation will most likely happen between the 12th and 15th days, counting day 1 as the first day of your last period.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: That's amazing! So each month, the woman produces these eggs and then waits for them to be fertilized?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Actually, every woman is already born with over four hundred thousand eggs! Some will start dying off immediately and others released during her fertile period.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What about the guys? I know they produce sperm and stuff.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: That’s right! The man’s body has a tiny factory that produces sperm twenty four hours a day! Each ejaculation will release about a hundred million sperm so the factory is always pretty busy. The sole purpose of a sperm's life is to fertilize the woman's egg.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: So, then we basically need to put one-and-one together so we can have babies right?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Yes, the man will have an orgasm during intercourse and ejaculate sperm and semen. Now this is where the race begins and all those millions of sperm will race and swim from the cervix, through the uterus to the fallopian tubes. This could take anywhere from forty five minutes to twelve hours! Not all of them make it, since some go the wrong way and get lost or simply die. Many will actually reach the egg but only one will penetrate it and fertilize it. Once this happens, the egg instantly changes and creates a protective shield once the sperm is safely inside.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: And then? That's it?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Well, the egg will be fertilized within about 24 hours of its release. The genetic material from the sperm combines with the genetic material in the egg to create a new cell that will rapidly start dividing. The woman is not actually pregnant until that bundle of new cells, known as the embryo, travels the rest of the way down the fallopian tube and attaches itself to the wall of her uterus. Any other questions? Then let's move on.

conversation.text: Just give me a second; I’ll be right up.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I ran a virus scan on your computer, and it turns out that you have a lot of infected files!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: But I’m quite careful when I’m browsing the internet, I have no idea how I could have picked up a virus.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, you have to make sure that your anti-virus software is updated regularly; yours wasn't up to date, that's probably what was causing your problems.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Ok. Anything else?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, try not to kick or hit the computer!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Um yeah… Sorry about that.

title: EnglishPod 8 - Elementary - What is your name again

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Nick! How's it going?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Oh, hey...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: What are you doing in this neightbourhood? Do you live around here?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Actually, my office is right around the corner.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: It was great to meet you last week at the conference. I really enjoyed our conversation about foreign investment.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, yeah, it was really interesting. You know, I'm in a bit of a hurry, but here's my card. We should definitely meet up again and continue our discussion.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Sure, you still have my contact details, right ?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You know what, this is really embarrassing, but your name has just slipped my mind. Can you remind me?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Sure, my name is Ana Ferris. Don't worry about it; it happens to me all the time. I'm terrible with names too.

conversation.text: Hello, I’m here to see Mr. Corleone.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Right this way, sir.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Charlie! What can I do for you?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Mr. Corlone, I’m really sorry to trouble you, but I need your help.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Anything for you, Charlie! Your father was like a brother to me.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, sir, you see, this recession has hit me pretty hard; I lost my job and I’m in a lot of debt.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: I see……

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, you know, I’ve got credit card bills, car payments, I’ve got to pay my mortgage; and on top of all that, I have to pay my son’s college tuition.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: So you’re asking for a loan.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, I just thought maybe you could help me out.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: What? At a time like this? I’m broke too, you know! You’re not the only one who has been hit by the recession! I lost half my money in the stock market crash! Go on! Get outta here!

title: EnglishPod 17 - Elementary - Here Comes the Bride

conversation.text: Don't be mean. Look, here come the bridesmaids! Their dresses look beautiful!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Who are those kids walking down the aisle?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: That's the flower girl and the ring bearer. I'm pretty sure they're the groom's niece and nephew. Oh, they look so cute!

conversation.speaker: B

conversation.speaker: A

title: EnglishPod 20 - Elementary - I can see clearly now

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Hello, Arthur. What seems to be the problem?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Hey doc. Well, I think I might need glasses. I'm getting headaches, and I really struggle to see things that are far away. But I have always had 20/20 vision.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Sounds like you may be far-sighted. OK, then, cover your left eye and read the chart in front of you.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Mmm… X, E, R, 3, a question mark, and I can't quite make out the other symbol but I think it's the peace sign.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Wow, Arthur! You're as blind as a bat!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, I know, my vision is really blurry at times.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Ok, then, head on over to the other room and pick out some frames while I fill out your prescription.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Thanks, doc!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Arthur, that's the bathroom.

title: EnglishPod 36 - Elementary - I'm sorry I love you 3

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Steven! Where have you been? I've been trying to get a hold of you for hours!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I... um... there was an emergency at work, so...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I was waiting for you in the restaurant for three hours! And you didn't even have the decency to call me! Do you have any idea how embarrassed I was?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Honey, I promise this won't happen again, it's just that I...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Yeah, right. I've heard it all before. I'm not going to take any more of your empty promises. This is the fifth time you've stood me up in two weeks! You need to get your priorities straight. I'm tired of you putting your job first all the time!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Come on, Veronica, that's not fair. I do care about you a lot, you know that. I tried to ...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: You know what? Maybe we should just take a break. I need some time to think about where this relationship is heading.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: But...Veronica, would you just listen to me? There was a fire alarm at my office building today and I was stuck...

conversation.text: So, Casey, how are things going with the photos for the press kit?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: You've had over a month to get this finalized! Why are things delayed?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, the thing is, we ran into a lot of problems...

conversation.speaker: B

I had trouble booking the the photographer, and then Michael was sick for three weeks, so I couldn't include him in the photos, and the design team lost all the files, so I had to redo the pictures.

conversation.text: This is an exclusive design by DaMarco! It's a bargain at that price.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, I don't know. I think I'll shop around.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Okay, okay, how about one hundred dollars?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: That's still more than I wanted to spend. What if I take both dresses?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Okay, I can give you a special discount, just because you seem like a nice person. One hundred and ninety dollars for both.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I don't know... It's still a bit pricey.... Thanks anyway.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Okay, my final price! One hundred dollars for both! That's two for the price of one. That's my last offer!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Great! You've got a deal!

title: EnglishPod 69 - Elementary - How Would You Like Your Eggs

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Wow, you're up early today! What's for breakfast?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, I felt like baking, so I made some muffins.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Smells good! I'll make some coffee. Do you want me to make you some eggs?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Sure, I’ll take mine, sunny side up.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Eww, I don't know how you can eat your eggs like that! Ever since I was small, I've had eggs and soldiers.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You know, my dad had scrambled eggs eggs every morning for twenty years. It drove my mom crazy!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: You know what really drives me crazy? When I ask for soft boiled eggs, and they overcook them, so they come out hard boiled! How can you dip your toast into a hard boiled egg?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You're so picky sometimes.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Here you go, honey, fried eggs.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Dammit! I asked for sunny side up! How many times do I have to tell you.

title: EnglishPod 88 - Elementary - Asking for a Raise

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Hey, you're early! Where's everyone?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well... I told them not to come. I made a reservation just for the two of us. I thought we could have an quiet evening all to ourselves.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Oh... why?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Jennifer, there's something I wanna ask you.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Sure. What is it?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Hmm... okay, here's the thing. I've always seen you as more than just a friend, and I can't take it any more. I know you better than anyone, I know the pros and cons of your personality, I even know what side of the bed is yours! I think we would be great together, don't you?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Are you serious? We've been friends for years! We can't just change that overnight!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I know! I never had the guts to tell you... until today. So, what do you say? Are you willing to give me a shot?

conversation.text: Alright, ladies and gentlemen. We've been hired to build a deck on this here house, and turn this boring and drab lawn into a backyard oasis. There is one catch, though. It's going to be tough, but we've got a great team here, and I know that together we can tackle this project. That being said, let's get to work!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: That's right. Now, remember, we've been over the plans, but we really need to make sure that everything is up to code. The home inspectors here are pretty thorough, so please make sure you follow the plans exactly. And remember the carpenter's rule of thumb: measure twice and cut once.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Okay, guys. Let's get at it. Bob! Pass me that hammer! The nails won't go in; the wood is too hard. I think I'm gonna need the nail gun. That did it!

conversation.speaker: C

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I think you should sand the edges. Look at all these splinters, someone could get hurt. Geez...you gotta take pride in your work!

conversation.speaker: C

title: EnglishPod 104 - Elementary - New Guy in Town 9

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Welcome ski lovers of all ages! My name is Rick Fields and here with me is the man that needs no introduction, Bob Copeland.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Thank you, Rick! What a beautiful day here in Aspen, Colorado where the sun is shinning, and we've got twelve inches of fresh powder. It doesn't get much better than this.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: That's right, Bob, but today we have a special treat for our viewers. We're joined here by Ian Roussy, the four-time giant slalom champion. And on this special edition of the show, Ian is going to teach us the basics of skiing! So, let's hit the slopes!

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Well, first off, let's get those boots on. You're going to want to make sure your boots fit snugly. That's right; now snap them into your bindings. And you're also going to want a good pair of goggles to protect your eyes. It's a bright day today, so there's going to be a lot of glare out there on the slopes. We don't want you hitting any of those moguls!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Bob, since you're a beginner skier and might take a few spills, it is a good idea to have a good warm pair of dry ski gloves.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Easy there, Rick! Well, let's head on over to the chairlift, and test your skills! All right, we're up here on the bunny hill, so, Bob, why don't you do a few snow-plow turns. Gnarly run, Rick! Nice carving! You've got some mad skills! That was sick!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: You wanna see gnarley? Well, see that bump over there, I'm going to catch some major air.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Butt plant!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Ha ha ha! He lost his skis! Yard sale!!!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Ahem, well. Thanks for joining us here today, I think that about does it. Bob, Ian, time for some après-ski?

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: No way, man! We're off to grab some freshies!!!

title: EnglishPod 134 - Elementary - Daily Life - Asking for a Raise

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Seriously, I don't know why we need to get a new TV.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Honey I told you already. I can't appreciate the graphics level and detail of the games on my Playstation 3 on our old TV.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Good afternoon folks! How can I be of service today?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I'm looking to upgrade to a newer, bigger television set.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: You've come to the right place! What size are you looking for?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Just a normal sized TV for our living room.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: I see. Well this set here is on sale. It's a forty six inch HDTV screen and has all the works. Three HDMI connectors, USB, VGA and S - Video ports. It even has a DVI port so you can hook up your PC or laptop! This is without a doubt the complete home theater experience!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: This is exactly what I need! Can you imagine watching movies or playing video games on this thing?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Honey, I think it's a bit too big. I don't even think it will fit in our living room.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Not to worry, we will deliver and install it in your home. It comes with a wall mount so you can just hang it on the wall like a picture!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: This is great! How much will this set me back?

conversation.speaker: C

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I'll take it!

title: EnglishPod 32 - Intermediate - Opening a Bank Account

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Next, please. May I help you, sir?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Hello, yes, I'd like to open a bank account.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Certainly, I can can help you with that. What type of account would you like to open? A chequing or a savings account?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What What features do they offer?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Well, if you just take a look here, see, with our chequing account, you can have unlimited daily transactions for a small monthly fee, and our savings account has a higher interest rate, but you must carry a minimum balance of $ 10,000 dollars.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I see, well, I think I'm more interested in a chequing account; I like to have easy access to my money.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Alright, then, with this chequing account you'll be issued a debit card and a cheque book. Will you require overdraft protection? There is an extra fee for that.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: No, that won't be necessary.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: In that case, I'll get you to fill out this paperwork; I'll need your social insurance number, and two pieces of government ID. If you could just sign here, and here, and here; we'll be all set. Would you like to make a deposit today?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yes, I'd like to deposit one billion dollars.

title: EnglishPod 35 - Intermediate - He's not a good fit

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: So, Lauren, I just wanted to talk to you quickly about our new customer support representative, Jason Huntley.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Sure, what's up?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Basically, I've got a few concerns about him, and the bottom line is, I don't think he's a good fit for our company.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Okay... what makes you say that? I thought you were pleased with his overall performance. Didn't you just tell me last week how impressed you were with his attitude?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Yeah, his attitude is great, but he's really unreliable. Sometimes he's really productive, but then other times... take last Tuesday for instance, he was forty-five minutes late for our morning meeting!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, I'm sure he had a perfectly good reason...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: But that's not the only thing... you know, he really doesn't have the best work ethic, I'm constantly catching him on MSN and Facebook when he should be talking to clients.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, but come on, Geoff, as if you don't check Facebook at work. Look, you hired this guy, we've invested a lot of time and money in his training, so now it's up to you to coach him. Make it work, Geoff!

title: EnglishPod 43 - Intermediate - Applying for a Visa

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: So, you're applying for a B2 visa, where is your final destination and what's the purpose of your trip to the United States?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I'm going to visit my brother; he's just had a baby. He lives in Minneapolis.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: And how long do you you plan to remain in the United States?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I'll be here for approximately three weeks. See, here's my return ticket for the twenty-sixth of March.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: And, who is sponsoring your trip?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: My brother, here, this is an invitation letter from him. I will stay with him and his family in their home.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Alright, tell me about the ties you have to your home country.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, I own a house; actually, I'm leaving my dog there with my neighbors. I have a car at home, and oh, my job! I'm employed by Tornel as an engineer. Actually, I only have three weeks' vacation, so I have to go back to work at the end of March.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: And what evidence do you have that you are financially independent?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, I do have assets in my country; like I said, I own a house, and see, here's a bank statement showing my investments, and my bank balance.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I'm sorry, sir, we cannot grant you a B2 visa at this time, instead, you are granted a resident visa! Congratulations, you are the millionth person to apply for a visa! You win! Congratulations!

title: EnglishPod 56 - Intermediate - Planning a Bank Robbery

conversation.text: All right, so this is what we are going to do. I've carefully mapped this out, so don't screw it up. Mr. Rabbit, you and Mr. Fox will go into the bank wearing these uniforms. We managed to get replicas of the one the guards wear when they pick up the money.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Got it.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: No problem, boss.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: When you get inside, tell them that you are filling in for Carl and Tom, and say that they are on another route today. Don't lose your cool. Just act natural.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: You let him.

conversation.text: What!?

conversation.speaker: B

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Okay, shut up. Only take as much money as you can fit in these bags. Don’t get greedy! Are you ready? Let's go.

title: EnglishPod 64 - Intermediate - I'm Sorry I Love You 6

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Wait! Doctor how is this possible? I haven't cheated on my boyfriend!

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: I have something to confess... I'm sorry Veronica, I lied.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Wait... what? What do do you mean?

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: I lied. You aren't even pregnant; there's no bun in the oven. I was just so overwhelmed with jealousy that I couldn't help myself. Veronica I love you!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What are you talking about!!! Who are you?

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: It's me! Daniel, don't you remember me? From high school. I sat behind you every day in class! I used to go to every football game and watch you in the cheerleading squad!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You are insane! We never even spoke! Why did you lie like that to my boyfriend?

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Because Veronica... It's not fair! I love you; I have since the first day we met! Everything was going fine until that jerk came into the picture and ruined everything! I went to med school and became a doctor for you! You always said how you wanted to marry a doctor! You will be mine now... one way or another...

title: EnglishPod 100 - Intermediate - Where are you from

conversation.text: Hi! Crenshaw and Hawthorne, at the Holiday Inn that is on that corner.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Sure thing. So, where are you flying in from?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: From China.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Really? You don't look very Chinese to me, if you don't mind me saying so.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: It's fine. I am actually from Mexico. I was in China on a business trip, visiting some local companies that manufacture bathroom products.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Wow sounds interesting! Excuse me if I am being a bit nosy but, how old are you?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Don't you know it's rude to ask a lady her age?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Don't get me wrong! It's just that you seem so young and already doing business overseas!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well thank you! In that case, I am 26 years old, and what about yourself?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I am 40 years old and was born and raised here in the good old U.S of A, although I have some Colombian heritage.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Really? That's great! Do you speak some Spanish?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Uh... yeah.. of course!

conversation.speaker: B

title: EnglishPod 131 - Intermediate - Daily Life - Buying a Suit

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: We now stand ten years past the midpoint of a century that has witnessed four major wars among great nations. Three of these involved our own country. Despite the carnage of these conflicts, America is today the strongest, the most influential and most productive nation in the world. We are understandably proud of this pre-eminence, yet we realize that America's leadership and prestige depend, not merely upon our unmatched material progress, riches and military strength, but on how we use our power in the interests of world peace and human betterment.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Throughout America's adventure in free government, such basic purposes have been to keep the peace; to foster progress in human achievement, and to enhance liberty, dignity and integrity among peoples and among nations.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: We pray that peoples of all faiths, all races, all nations, may have their great human needs satisfied; that those now denied opportunity shall come to enjoy it to the full; that all who yearn for freedom may experience its spiritual blessings; that those who have freedom will understand, also, its heavy responsibilities; that all who are insensitive to the needs of others will learn charity; that the scourges of poverty, disease and ignorance will be made to disappear from the earth, and that, in the goodness of time, all peoples will come to live together in a peace guaranteed by the binding force of mutual respect and love.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Now, on Friday noon, I am to become a private citizen. I am proud to do so. I look forward to it. Thank you, and good night.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Good afternoon! Did you call for a plumber?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yes, yes I did. Please come in! I'm so glad you came! This old house is falling apart! Come on into the bathroom. See, here, there's water leaking everywhere!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I see. Let me have a look. It seems that your toilet is clogged, and that's why it won't flush. Let me just get my plunger. No, that's not working either. I suspect that there's some sort of foreign object in the pipes that's causing a blockage. That's what's making your toilet overflow.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Oh, that must be because of my four-year-old daughter. She is always flushing things down the toilet. You know how kids are.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Yeah, I have a little one myself. Anyway, these water pipes are really rusty, so they also should be changed. That could be causing water to not drain completely; that might lead to more problems in the future. I would also suggest fixing this faucet that isn't shutting off properly. I could have it all finished by today if it's urgent.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: That would be great! Is it expensive?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Let's see... I would say about eight hundred dollars.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What? That's more than I make in a day and I'm a heart surgeon!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Honey, do you have a second?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Sure! Are you okay? You seem a bit worried. What's on your mind?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: We need to talk.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Okay...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I've been thinking, and well, I think we need to start seeing other people.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What? Why? I mean, we've had our ups and downs, and we have the occasional disagreement, but we're happy together, aren't we?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: That's just it, I'm not happy anymore, Tim. It's not you, it's me. I know that I can be hard to deal with, and you are a great guy! You are the type of guy that any woman would kill for!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: So, what are you saying? You're breaking up with me because I'm perfect?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Tim, you are too good for me. You deserve someone who can make you smile and make you happy the way that you made me happy. Oh, I could say that I'll be all you need, but that would be a lie. I know I'd only hurt you, I know I'd only make you cry.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Baby, come on. Don't do this to me! Whatever it is, we can work it out. Just give me another chance! I know that we can get through this, but we gotta stick together! Don't leave me.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I can't, Tim. I hope someday you can find some way to understand I'm only doing this for you. I don't really wanna go but, deep in my heart I know this is the kindest thing to do.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Laura...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Here are your keys. I'll send my sister to pick up the rest of my things next week. I'm sorry, Tim. I wish you all the best, and I hope that one day we can meet again. I'll always love you. Goodbye.

conversation.speaker: B

conversation.speaker: A

title: EnglishPod 34 - Upper Intermediate - Live from Washington

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: This is Madeline Wright, for BCC News reporting live from Washington D. C. where, very shortly, the new President will deliver his inaugural address. Just moments ago, the President was sworn in to office; following the United States Constitution the president swore an oath to faithfully execute the office of the presidency.

conversation.speaker: B

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Well, Tom, true to American tradition, the band has just played Hail to the Chief, and the President has been honored by a 21 gun salute. Now we're waiting for the President to take to the stage and deliver his speech. Tom, it's like a who's who of the political world here on Capital Hill, with dignitaries representing several different countries.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What's the mood on the ground like, Madeline?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: In a word, the mood here is electric. The excitement in the air is palpable; I've never seen a larger crowd here on Capital Hill, and the audience is shouting crying, and embracing each other. On this, a most historic day, you can feel the hope and the excitement in the air. The twentieth of January will go down in history as the... Oh, Tom, it looks like the President is about to to begin...

title: EnglishPod 90 - Upper Intermediate - I'm Sorry I Love You 8

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Veronica! Veronica! Veronica! Are you OK?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Steven! What's going on! Who were those guys? I didn't know you have a gun! What's going on!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I will come clean as soon as we get to safety, OK? For now, you have to trust me, please! I would never do anything to hurt you.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Steven, I...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Okay, run! I haven't been completely honest with you Veronica, I'm sorry. I'm not a fireman. I'm not even from the United States. I'm a spy for the Indian government.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What? Why didn't you tell me before? What are you doing here?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: When I was a young boy, I used to play cricket my father back in my hometown of Hyderabad. It was a peaceful town, and my father was a renowned chemist. One day, he was approached by members of the CIA, claiming that my father had made the discovery of the millennium in his small lab back at the university where he taught bio-chemistry. I never saw him again. I vowed to discover the whereabouts of my father and consequently joined the Indian Intelligence Bureau.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: What does that have to do with those men shooting at us? Most importantly, why did you lie to me!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I'm sorry, I wasn't supposed to meet you. I wasn't supposed to fall in love with you, but you have to believe me when I tell you that what I feel for you is real.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I can't believe this! Why are all these things happening to me! I can't take it anymore! Let me out of the car!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Veronica, wait!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: What's up? You don't look too good.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, my head hurts, that's all. I've been in physics class all day. It's killer!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I liked physics. It's all math, really; arcs, curves, velocity, cool stuff.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, yeah, but today's lesson was all about the creation of the universe.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: A physics class about the creation of the universe? That's some pretty unscientific language there. Sounds more religous to me.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: It's all religion. Take the theory of the Big Bang. How is it possible that all of the stuff in the universe comes from an explosion? That's no better than Atlas carrying the globe on his back or African myths about turtles and stuff.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Turtles? Whatever... Look, all that's required for the creation of matter an imbalance of particles and anti-particles. At least, that's what the math says.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Math, shmath. What's the evidence?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: There is evidence! You know Edwin Hubble? He's the guy who in the early twentieth century was the first scientist to measure the drift of matter in the universe, thus advancing notions of an expanding universe. What would it be expanding from? Well, the Big Bang... DUH!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Anyway, it's just a theory. Why do people go around touting theories? Where's the scientific rigor in that?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Dude, don't equivocate. A theory only becomes a theory after withstanding rigorous testing. You slept through class, didn't you?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Agh! You're making my head hurt again! Quit with the questions!

We can expect clear skies, but it will be quite cold, with temperatures hovering around the thirty degree mark.

Winds will be coming in from the North East, with gusts reaching twenty-three miles per hour. Salt Lake City can expect the rain to turn to sleet in the evening. Things are looking a bit better for the South; we'll see cloudy skies with a chance of showers. Later in the day, we can expect partly-cloudy skies, with a forecast high of thirty-eight degrees.

title: EnglishPod 137 - Upper Intermediate - Getting Internet Service

conversation.text: Hi. I would like to get an internet plan for my house.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Of course. We have three different plans with different prices you can choose from. The first one is the cheapest but most basic plan which is thirty dollars a month. This is for broadband internet with a download speed of five hundred and twelve kbps.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I have no idea what kbps means. I just want to be able to get online, play games and chat with my friends. Oh, and watch movies online as well.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Well, this connection might be a bit too slow for your needs. I suggest you get the premium package for fifty dollars a month which includes a connection speed of two megabytes. That way you can play games online without any lag. This package also includes a wireless router and a personal firewall absolutely free!

conversation.speaker: B

conversation.speaker: A

conversation.speaker: A

conversation.speaker: A

conversation.text: What do you mean? My daddy gave me this car for my birthday last month. It's brand new!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Well missy, the white smoke that you saw is steam from the radiator. You overheated your engine so now the pistons are busted and so is your transmission. You should have called us and we could have towed you over here when your car died.

conversation.speaker: B

conversation.speaker: A

title: EnglishPod 108 - Upper Intermediate - Bad news, boss

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: ... Now that we have been over the gory details of our disastrous first quarter, Ed! Give us some good news. How are things looking for us in terms of sales this month?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Uh well...would you like the bad news first or the really bad news?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: What? Ed, don't tell me you only have bad news!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well sir, our sales have dropped, no plunged, fifty percent in the past month alone. We are currently overstocked and overstaffed and our profits are falling fast. The market is in recession and we have no way of moving our inventory, or getting rid of our staff. If we consider redundancies, it would cost us a fortune because of the new regulations governing compensation packages. It's a real mess.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: For crying out loud... How fast are we losing money?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Um...how can I put this? Let's just say that at this pace, we will be filing for Chapter eleven in less than three months.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: What! Geez! How could this have happened? So what's the bad news?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Oh, that's the really bad news. Our supplier suffered QC problems and, well, half of our production is faulty. We're going to have to recall all items sold in the last quarter. And the worst part? We're going to have to shoulder this cost.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Are you joking? Get the supplier on the line now! They have to assume the costs of this mess!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: We tried that, sir. The factory has gone under and the owner apparently has fled the country.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: We're doomed!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: There is some really good news though!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Really? What!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I got offered a new job!

title: EnglishPod 107 - Upper Intermediate - Complaining at a Restaurant

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Excuse me, waiter? Waiter!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yes, sir? What can I do for you?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I've been sitting here for the past twenty minutes and no one has offered me a glass of water, brought any bread to the table and our appetizers haven't been served yet! You know, in this kind of establishment, I'd expect much better service.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I am sorry, sir. I'll check on your order right away.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Relax honey, the place is busy tonight, but I've heard the food is amazing. Anyway...

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Here you are, sir. The foie gras for the lady, and a mushroom soup for you.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Waiter, I ordered a cream of mushroom soup with asparagus. This soup is obviously too runny, and it's over-seasoned. It's completely inedible!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Okay, I do apologize for that. Can I bring you another soup, or would you like to order something else?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Take this foie gras back as well, it's rubbery and completely overcooked. And look at the portion size! How can you charge twenty-five dollars for a sliver of duck liver?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Right away... sir.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Honey come on! The foie gras was fine, why are you making such a big deal? Are you trying to get our meal comped again?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: What do you mean? We are paying for this. If I'm shelling out my hard earned bucks, I expect value for money!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Here you are, sir. I hope it is alright now. The chef has prepared it specially for you.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Yes, fine.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Honey, are you alright?

title: EnglishPod 47 - Advanced - Just in Time Strategy

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I called this meeting today in order to discuss our manufacturing plan. As I'm sure you're all aware, with the credit crunch, and the global financial crisis, we're obligated to look for more cost efficient ways of producing our goods. We don't want to have to be looking at redundancies. So, we've outlined a brief plan to implement the just-in-time philosophy.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: We have two basic points that we want to focus on. First of all, we want to reduce our lead time.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Why would want to do that? I think this is not an area that really needs to be worked on.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, we want to reduce production and delivery lead timesfor better overall efficiency.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Right, production lead times can be reduced by moving work stations closer together, reducing queue length, like for example, reducing the number of jobs waiting to be processed at a given machine, and improving the coordination and cooperation between successive processes. Delivery lead times can be reduced through close cooperation with suppliers, possibly by inducing suppliers to locate closer to the factory or working with a faster shipping company.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: I see… That makes sense.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: The second point is that we want to require supplier quality assurance and implement a zero defects quality program. We currently have far too many errors that lead to defective items and therefore, they must be eliminated. A quality control at the source program must be implemented to give workers the personal responsibility for the quality of the work they do, and the authority to stop production when something goes wrong.

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: I'm with you on this one. It’s essential that we reduce these errors; we've got to force our suppliers to reduce their mistakes.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Exactly. Well, let's look at how we're going to put this plan into action. First...(fade out)

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Oh honey, this is so romantic! I have never seen so many stars before! It's beautiful!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: See that constellation there? That's Orion! And the very bright star? Well, it's not a star since it doesn't blink. That's actually Venus.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: What's that big flashy one?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I don't know... I think it's a UFO!

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Greetings earthlings. I come from afar, from a distant galaxy known only to a few.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Why are you here? Where did you come from?

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: We have been observing you for the last three thousand years. We have seen the amazing capacity that humans have to create such wonders as the Taj Mahal or masterpieces such as the Haffner symphony. Unfortunately, your intelligence and creativity does not come without consequence. Your ambition and desire for more will be your downfall, and we are here to save your planet from you.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You think you have us figured out? What gives you the right to come and judge us? Who are you to play God with our fate?

conversation.speaker: C
conversation.text: Silence human! It is that belligerent attitude that has caused years of pain and anguish among yourselves! Now you will pay the price!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Welcome back movie lovers to another " Premier Movie Review". My name is Richard Clarke and I am joined today by the very erudite David Watson.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Thank you Dick. Today we are going to talk about the movie " Lion King". Tell me Dave, what is your impression of this film?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Well, I think this film is simply a fable, depicting man's eternal greed for power, and in my opinion, it's a very fine film. Even despite the accusations of plagiarism traditional folk tales from other countries. The musical score was amazing, the animation was very well done, and the story was simply enchanting.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I think otherwise. Even though the animation was technically strong, and as you say, the score and songs performed by Elton John were great, the film lacks a certain originality; it lacked heart. And I would dare to say, it was too predictable.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Predictable! How! Come on Dick, It's a G-rated movie! It's for the kids! It's not a thriller!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, that's just it. It did have some very dramatic and intense scenes For example when Mufasa dies, or the dark, grim portrayal of Scar. Even so, the film is linear. Mufasa dies, Simba runs away thinking it's his fault. Falls in love and returns to retake what is rightfully his. It's just too cliché.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: How can it be cliché? It's a fable! It's telling a time-honoured story! The movie make a point of how the hunger for power leads to corruption, and teaches children the value of respect, life and love.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You have always been so soft, Dave!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Open your heart Dick. Don't shut us out.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Anyway... That's all for today folks! Join us next time as we talk about "How to lose a guy in 10 days" I'm sure you'll love that one Dave!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Did you hear? The state is thinking of legalizing gambling in our city! Soon we are gonna have amazing hotels and casinos here which will be good for our business!

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Are you serious? Gambling is a vice industry built on deception and fed by the intentional exploitation of human weakness for the sole purpose of monetary gain! It disgusts me.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: What are you talking about? How does it exploit people?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Well, to begin with, Gambling is addictive, ruins marriages, destroys families and bankrupts communities. Once you are addicted it is very difficult to stop. People have lost their houses, cars and been left out on the street after becoming addicted. Secondly, it exploits because men become addicted to gambling most often because of the action and risk. Women gamble to escape, and senior citizens will start gambling for the social interaction. Underage gamblers often start gambling on sports with friends and then illegal bookies.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Geez! Now that I think about it, maybe legalizing gambling isn't such a good idea! Although, I have been to Las Vegas, and I didn't become addicted or anything like that.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You cannot predict who will become addicted to gambling. Now excuse me, I have a protest rally to organize!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Good evening, my fellow Americans. Three days from now, after a half-century of service of our country, I shall lay down the responsibilities of office as, in a traditional and solemn ceremony, the authority of the Presidency is vested in my successor. This evening I come to you with a message of leave-taking and farewell, and to share a few final thoughts with you, my countrymen.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Like every other citizen, I wish the new President, and all who will labor with him, Godspeed. I pray that the coming years will be blessed with peace and prosperity for all.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Our people expect their President and the Congress to find essential agreement on questions of great importance, the wise resolution of which will better shape the future of our great nation. My own relations with Congress began on a remote and tenuous basis when, long ago, a member of the Senate appointed me to West Point. I then had the pleasure of building more intimate relationship with Congress during the war and immediate post-war period. Finally, we have progressed to the mutually interdependent relationship we've had during these past eight years.

title: EnglishPod 116 - Advanced - You Missed The Deadline!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: And so, I just wanted to check in with you and find out where we are with this project. As you know, you've missed a fairly significant deadline last week, and this will negativity impact the team's ability to move forward with the next stages of this project.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: I know, I'm really sorry that I missed the deadline. But really, it wasn't my fault. You see, we had all of these unexpected technical problems at the last minute, and that I couldn't get into the database and extract the kind of information that I needed for the data analyis. You know, if the tech guys would have done their job and kept the CRM stable, then I wouldn't have missed my deadline.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Oh, come on! An excuse like that is tantamount to lying. You're essentially blaming the tech team for your time management issues, rather than accepting responsibility for the fact that you were procrastinating for the past two weeks.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: No, I'm not trying to pass the buck here; I know that it was me who is ultimately responsible for getting this done. But the thing is, I could have finished on time if the system hadn't gone down. And you know, with everything I've got going on now, I can't afford to waste time dealing with technical problems. I've got a lot on my plate and there are only twenty-four hours in a day...

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: I'm not going to accept this excuse. You're using these small technical glitches as a crutch and trying to rationalize the fact that you've missed your deadline. Look, we have standards and I expect you to live up to those standards. No more phoney excuses. If you're in over your head, you tell me. No more missed deadlines. Now, I want that data on my desk by nine am!

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: And therefore, global warming is the greatest deception of the early 21st century. Questions?

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Uh… yeah. In the lecture you said there’s more evidence in the scientific record supporting global cooling?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Well, yes, essentially, the historical record supports a theory of climate cycles. Warming and cooling are cooperating processes in the planetary eco-system.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: If that’s true and the planet is getting cooler, what explains the rapid melting of the polar ice caps and the dramatic rise in the global average temperatures?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: But are global temperatures rising? If you look at the data from nineteen seventy-five you’ll…

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: You’ll be misled. If you were serious, you would look at the record starting in the 1880’s. Then you would see how dramatically the earth’s temperature has changed.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Young lady, I beg to differ. Look, the point of the lecture was to emphasize that there is evidence for both sides, and I'm putting forth the argument that there's greater evidence in support of the global cooling hypothesis. Look, it's an indisputable fact that the public is being manipulated and scared into believing there’s some kind of climate crisis; this scaremongering is done, quite simply, for political reasons.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: But even without the uncomfortable reality that greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide contribute to global warming, isn’t the topic appropriate for politicians to discuss?

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Not if they want to use your tax dollars and mine to fund completely unnecessary initiatives.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, like conservation, protecting endangered species and investing in renewable energy. At the very least, you have to concede that this debate has the potential to end our dependence on foreign oil. Buying oil supports autocratic countries that use these revenues to devastating ends.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Why, I’ve never been so disrespected in all of my days. I’m a professor, a scientist and researcher of high regard.

conversation.speaker: B
conversation.text: Yeah, and a duplicitous one at that. Everyone knows you’re in the pocket of the oil lobby. Why should we trust your so-called findings more than tobacco institute studies which say smoking doesn’t harm health? You’re full of it.

conversation.speaker: A
conversation.text: Some people just cannot handle civil debate!
